title: Why is Demacia so Boring?
body:
This will probably get downvoted like crazy but I will comment anyway because i don't give a *concern*. Look at the recent state of Bilgewater with the "death" of Gangplank or Piltover with Jinx blowing things up like the Joker. These seem like such exciting locales but everybody gets along too well in Demacia and powerful champions are just kissing up to Jarvan like it's their job. 

Look at all the Demacian natives. They are all way too honorable and good. There is nobody there creating any conflict. Imagine watching Game of Thrones where you had the same king all the time, and everybody got along great. It would be awful. The only conflict they ever have is minor or with the Noxians who are infinitely more interesting. 

I suggest incorporating a coup of Jarvan's position, a void infiltration of the city or an Ao Shin reckoning for J4 and Shyvana killing dragons. Something to make this part of Runeterra come to life and not just be "where we put all the good people."

Edit: For some reason there are people that are arguing that Demacia is the most favorable quality of life environment in Runeterra as an (argument?) to what I initially posted. I completely agree that I would move there if I were in this world and there is nothing "wrong" with being surrounded by good people. I would not want to move my family next to a void portal or to a high conflict area if I physically lived in this world. However, my initial statement was that the lack of morally diverse characters and the successful orderly regime of J4 has created an environment where conflict (and thus exciting story) is rare and usually minor within the confines of the city.

replies.body:
Demacia is boring in the same way Warhammer 40K's Imperium is boring. Yes, it's explicitly coded as the good guys of the setting, but that is because:

1. There is a layer of "good-aligned" fantasy terms softening up the fact that they're dangerously close to being Nazi Germany.

2. More than half of the other factions in the setting are such terrible assholes that they look good by comparison.

Once you actually consider Demacia's characters, what they actually have is more like:

{{champion:114}} Demacia's extremely conservative culture has essentially ruined her life, seeing as she had to sacrifice her entire personal life and focus on becoming the perfect duelist just to maintain the traditional view of noble houses as perfect unblemished things.

{{champion:86}} His status as a cultural icon is easily defined by the saying "Kill one man and you become a murderer, kill a thousand and you become a hero". His biography has a quote "The most effective way to kill an opponent is to slice through the man next to him." attached, indicating that Garen's chivalry is usually punctuated by a healthy dose of slaughter.

{{champion:99}} Was forced to become a secret agent and go through soul-crushing training because of that very same view of noble houses as perfect things where every member must perform a purpose for the crown. Has severe PTSD and is basically a dead-eyed lunatic hiding behind a cheerful facade.

{{champion:236}}  and {{champion:67}} A pair of vengeful psychopaths only concerned with murdering undead and practitioners of dark magic regardless of the cost.

{{champion:59}} Solitary, secretive and kind of a jackass.

{{champion:133}} Effectively Demacia's Riven before the fall - a country bumpkin elevated to poster girl by her competence. Although she's always dreamed of knighthood, her own diary indicates that she has some doubts and reservations about Demacian nobility now that she's gotten personally acquainted with them.

{{champion:102}} Essentially a noble savage - a monster adopted into the military because she's dangerous enough to be useful, not because she's good.

...so really, once you come down to it, the only *good* people in Demacia who don't have serious emotional issues are Xin Zhao and Galio.

Honestly, it sounds like what makes Demacia boring to you is that it lacks any sort of in-fighting, which I don't know why it should. It's basically set up to be an antagonist to every single evil or questionable member of the setting, which is... everyone except Ionia, Piltover and Bandle City.

Also, I really wouldn't want them to give Demacia some conflict in the same way they gave it to Bilgewater. Retconning Miss Fortune into an extremely generic Vengence McBroody just to force some conflict into the setting was the lamest part of the story. :/

Agreed on most accounts. Except {{champion:5}} and {{champion:3}} too have emotional issues.

Before moving to Demacia, Xin Zhao was held captive in Noxus and subjected to the Fleshing; a gladiatorial spectacle where he would be pitted against increasingly large hoards of opponents until he was slain in battle. At that time, he was known as Viscero and was set to fight 300 opponents simultaneously. He and his opponents were personally rescued by King Jarvan II, and offered a spot in Demacia to get retribution for their torture. It would appear that he was recruited, like {{champion:102}} for his usefulness and disgust of Noxus, not for his moral standing. (As an aside, {{champion:12}} was also subject to the Fleshing, but he was not one of the 300 saved)

{{champion:3}} Failed in his mission to protect his creator, Durand, and was clearly left scarred. He stood towering over Durand's body as it withered into dust and it wasn't until he met Poppy that he went back to Demacia. Though arguably still pure of heart, he definitely bears his own emotional trauma.

Oh, I know they have emotional issues. What I'm saying is that they're only ones whose emotional issues do not interfere with their reading as good characters.

{{champion:5}} was forced into a battle arena where he needed to kill or be killed, but the experience didn't compromise his personality and morals. He stood strong and remained tethered to his concept of nobility and honor despite the trauma.

{{champion:3}} lost his master and reason to live, but he eventually managed to overcome it and find a new path in life without losing sight of loyalty and honor that sat at the core of his character.

They were tested by their experiences and came out stronger but unbroken. By comparison...

{{champion:86}} didn't question his country's ideals at all and instead chipperly went on his way of slaughtering thousands of people for justice and glory, because that is apparently okay when they're Noxian scum or whoever else you designate villain of the month.

{{champion:99}} completely broke from training and had to construct herself a new personality to function as a human being.

{{champion:114}} completely lost her own self in an effort to uphold her family's honor (though it might change because her story suffers from the usual Chapter 1-itis that a lot of Riot bios have).

Across Demacia, only Xin, Galio and Quinn had their goodness tested and came out stronger for it. Everyone else got the Imperium treatment of "It doesn't matter what emotional state you're in, so long as you still fight for the Emprah."
What exactly do you mean by "Chapter 1-itis"? I've read over her lore and am still not sure what you mean, but curious.

I mean that most characters in the game have their story begin but not really end or go in any particular direction.

Ahri has developed a sense of compassion and now seeks to become a good person, but her actual efforts in that regard are TO BE CONTINUED.

Fiora's quest to restore her family's honor is TO BE CONTINUED.

Ashe became the chieftain of the Avarosa and set out to unite Freljord, TO BE CONTINUED.

Trundle found his frozen club and became a chieftain, TO BE CONTINUED.

In fact, Ashe and Trundle were completely retconned and their personalities butchered in the process because their old stories were deemed to be too complete by the current narrative team.
Ah I see. Yeah, now you mention it I see what you mean. Damn a lot of champions have this problem.

Its a problem with the game's storytelling overall. The characters have to remain the same for gameplay purposes, which creates a very cliffhanger-based narrative. They can only have character and plot developement in bursts, like the Bilgewater event, or not at all, like in the Shurima event.

This^
A lot of interesting characters but none of them go anywhere narrative-wise.

What makes J4 a jackass?
The whole "he attacked swain in kalamanda"-thing was probably manipulated by the black rose.(not sure if that is still canon or not,but sions promo page did mention a "charade" involving J4s blood)

I parse J4 as a jackass because from what we've seen of him in the old lore so far, he is *incredibly* shady. He basically handles every situation the way he wants and doesn't show any concern for how others feel about it.

Shyvana idolizes him, but there are fairly strong implications in her lore that he brought her in as easy firepower.

Quinn's diary indicates that he's completely dismissive of Garen whenever it suits him.

He's willing to work with Noxians like Talon and Katarina if it helps him reach his goal.

His fighting style is described as incredibly violent.

People theorized that it's actually because J4 is LeBlanc masquerading as him, but the old narrative team outright said that was not the case. Which means Jarvan either had always been that way and his monster-hunting adventure brought out his darker streaks, or something out there broke him in ways we don't understand yet.

The bottom line is that he's way more morally gray, I'll even say more *amoral* than other Demacians, which is distressing once you consider that he's the crown prince with heavy involvement in politics. He actually *is* the Emprah.

And honestly, if Demacia's ruler is like that, then how can we expect its status as the nation of squeaky-clean goodness to be anything more than a thin layer of gloss on the surface?

so he's a jackass, in your opinion, because he:

1) Recruited a half-dragon instead of ignoring or killing her
2) Doesn't devote every waking moment idolizing Garen 
3) Is willing to cooperate with rivals to mutually beneficial ends
4) Is violent when he fights (?!?!)

I'm not really sure what you want from J4; it seems like you're trying REALLY hard to make him morally gray by twisting everything he's done into its most negative possible interpretation. To call him amoral, or a jackass, is a huge stretch. Pragmatic? Certainly. 'Morally gray'? Maybe, but certainly not for the reasons you listed.

Right now, I would mostly prefer if you didn't twist my words into something they didn't mean.

1. I made it pretty clear why him recruiting Shyvana is amoral. He recruited her because he wants easy firepower, not because he cares about her as a person. That's honestly not far off from ignoring her.

2. How did you even take "completely dismissive of the Commander of the Dauntless Vanguard and therefore one of the most important voices in his military" and warp it into "Doesn't devote every waking moment idolizing Garen"? There is a difference between idolizing and paying attention to your political advisers.

3. Katarina and Talon are not "rivals," they are everything Demacia stands against - anarchistic and honorless killers. Yes, him cooperating with them is a pretty big deal lore-wise, and is actually mentioned as completely unprecedented within the story. He's effectively willing to dismiss his nation's ideals for the sake of getting where he wants, which *is* amoral.

4. Have you read Jarvan's League Judgment? The one time we show him fighting, he goes completely berserk and attempts to rip Swain's head off with his bare hands. The thing isn't that he's simply violent, it's that his combat presence is described as that of a bloodthirsty monster. That, once again, doesn't code as "good". Or particularly moral for that matter.

1.Thats however what you assume.Shyvanas lore makes it sound like it was at least partly out of gratitude for her help.

2.And how was he completely dismissve?Quinn pointed out some valid problems with the assumptions that it was Talon who did the assassination and Jarvan listened to her and gave her the chance to prove her theory herself
He did not dismiss garens opinion either,since Garens unit still went to the place where they thought they would find evidence.

3.The thing is that demacia&noxus,were played for fools in this war and that Katarina and Talon were geniunly trying to help to prevent any unnecessary bloodshed.Jarvan did what he had to do to prevent unnecessary bloodshed.J4 didn't do what was expected of him because he knew it would lead only to a  pointless war,which would be even worse for his nation,so I dunno how that is amoral.

4.You want to blame him that he fights ferociously when his life is threatened?In a battle where your opponent is about to kill you,you have no time to spare,if you show mercy then you're probably gonna be killed.
Also he didn't want to rip swains head off,he was strangling swain,because he didn't had much energy left and swains ravens were picking away his body.
He did try to remove swains head at the beginning of the fight,which simply makes sense,I mean swain can regenerate by feeding of J4s life force,so he was in the dire need to end this fight as quickly as possible.

In the end I am not saying that Jarvan is a saint,but calling him a jackass for these things seems kind of over the top.
KiIlled my dad thanks ill join your army now
Killed the dragon that killed her dad. Who was also a dragon.

I wasn't trying to twist your words, but i don't think my points were invalid responses to your own. The main source of my annoyance at this line of thinking (beyond calling him a 'jackass') is this repeated pattern of playing 'gotcha' with characters who would align 'Lawful Good' if this were D&D, namely Demacia. J4 recruited a half dragon? He must have had ulterior motives! The end of his fight with Swain got brutal? What a violent hypocrite! 

Jarvan is the heir to a militaristic nation beset on all sides by void monsters, killer ghosts, and a long-established rival power waiting for the slightest weakness to take advantage of. It makes perfect sense within the story that Jarvan 4 would have a violent side to his nature, and while he likely did consider the benefit of having the power of a half-dragon at his side when he recruited Shyvana, that doesn't exclude the positive reasons he asked her to join him. Pragmatic thinking doesn't make him the fascist, manipulative 'jackass' some here are claiming him to be. 

From the lore I've read, Jarvan 4 is a better leader than anyone else is in Runeterra. He listens to his advisers and treats them with respect, no matter where they came from (Quinn), has great acceptance towards other races (Shyvana, Xin Zhao), and doesn't eliminate or assassinate his political rivals. He has demonstrated violence before, but there is such a thing as "righteous fury".

Violence of any kind, by the highest standard, isn't moral, but piling onto Jarvan 4 about it is nonsensical. No, he's not a perfect person, but that's because he's a _human being_. As a member of the world of League of Legends, he has to blend righteousness with practicality; but the important thing to remember is when it comes down to it, Jarvan will do the right thing.

In that image where he attacked Swain, you can see LeBlanc's reflection in Swain's chestplate, implying she's taking the form of J4.
And yeah, that's not canon anymore.
Yeah,but the Sion promo implies that something like this still happened at one point(its easily possible that the kalamanda incident still happened,just that they battled it out)

I think Demacia is very fine how it is right now. Every city/state has its own personalty and most of my fav characters come from Demacia. 
I don't think Demacia is boring ):

Also Demacia isn't the "Good" people and Noxus isn't really the "Bad" people at least from my understanding of it. They both have different values and beliefs how their cultures should work and Noxus just happens to run toward the slightly more dark side of the spectrum.

I don't see why everyone thinks that a character (or characters) being good can't lead to anything interesting. There's tons of conflict that can come from being good- for instance, putting Demacia in situations where it's hard to see what IS good. Maybe there's situations where you can pit lawful versus good. Have characters have internal conflict where they wonder if what they're doing is right. I think that would be a better direction to go for than the champions in Demacia suddenly becoming grey and gritty. Grey and gritty is /tiresome/. It's just as common as good vs evil tropes now, if not more so since everyone wants to be edgy these days. We already have Bilgewater, Zaun, Piltover, as a source of grey characters. Noxus too even. 

I'm afraid that suddenly Demacia is just going to be turned into some tyrannical dictatorship all in the name of being 'grey', when it doesn't fit the theme of so many of the already established characters. Honestly, I think it's lazy writing if Riot can't make good interesting.

We just need to know more about Demacia than that they like to distribute/enforce their ideal of JUSTICE.

I like the mystery behind the Demacian royalty, and the uniformity. The unique people stand out much more surrounded by identical champions. I really want to see the underbelly of Demacia. Vayne's parents were murdered by a witch. Why would an evil witch live there and live in fear of being found out, when she could go to Noxus and be praised for her strengths?

Look at how places like the Freljord and Shurima and Bilgewater transformed from what we saw originally to something a lot more unique and interesting than what they originally were after a healthy dosage of fleshing out.

Demacia could most certainly use something like that, a heavy pass-over by the lore team to transform it from what it currently is to something greater to better fit into the new lore and the world at large.
